summary: This is a transcript of oral arguments before Judge Paul A. Engelmayer in the FOIA case The New York Times Company v. Federal Bureau of Prisons. The arguments focus on the government's use of FOIA Exemption 7(A) to withhold documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death, citing potential interference with the pending criminal prosecutions of BOP officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, and the capital case of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. The judge expresses skepticism about the breadth of the withholdings and indicates he will likely conduct an in-camera review.

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: Presiding judge over the FOIA case between The New York Times and the Federal Bureau of Prisons. He questions the government's broad application of FOIA exemptions.

persons.name: David Edward McCraw
persons.role: Attorney for The New York Times Company
persons.context: Represents The New York Times in the FOIA lawsuit. Argues against the government's broad withholdings under Exemption 7(A), particularly regarding the Tartaglione and Noel cases.

persons.name: Alexandra Settelmayer
persons.role: Attorney for The New York Times Company
persons.context: Co-counsel for The New York Times. Presents arguments regarding FOIA Exemption 5 and the foreseeable harm requirement.

persons.name: Steven
persons.context: Represents the Federal Bureau of Prisons (the government). Defends the use of FOIA Exemptions 7(A) and 5 to withhold documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, citing ongoing criminal proceedings.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Listed as appearing for the government, though not actively speaking in this transcript.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FOIA request. His incarceration, apparent suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, and death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) are central to the documents being sought.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: A defendant in a capital case who was briefly housed with Jeffrey Epstein. His defense may use his interactions with Epstein (specifically reporting Epstein's July 23 suicide attempt) as a mitigating factor, which the government cites as a reason to withhold documents under Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons officer charged in connection with falsifying records related to inmate counts on the night of Jeffrey Epstein's death. Her ongoing prosecution is a primary basis for the government's Exemption 7(A) withholdings.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons officer charged alongside Tova Noel. His ongoing prosecution is also cited as a basis for Exemption 7(A) withholdings.

persons.name: Capone
persons.context: A BOP official who submitted declarations supporting the government's FOIA withholdings. His declarations are referenced throughout the arguments to justify categorical exemptions.

persons.name: Christenson
persons.context: Submitted a declaration for the government regarding Exemption 5 withholdings. His boilerplate explanations are criticized by The Times' counsel.

persons.name: Oetken
persons.context: A judge in the Southern District of New York whose standard for evaluating FOIA Exemption 7(A) is discussed as an alternative to a stricter "per-se rule."

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The government is withholding approximately 3,500 pages of BOP documents related to Jeffrey Epstein under FOIA Exemptions 7(A) and 5.

The primary justification for withholding under Exemption 7(A) is the potential interference with the criminal prosecutions of BOP officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, and the capital case of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione.
Judge Engelmayer is highly skeptical of the government's broad, categorical withholdings, describing them as having a "trust us" quality and expressing concern that "too much has been withheld."
The judge indicates he will likely order the government to produce the withheld documents for in-camera review so he can independently assess the applicability of the claimed exemptions.
The New York Times's core interest is in understanding "government failure" and providing public oversight into how Epstein's suicide occurred while in BOP custody.
